H0.text: Oviparous is the term that describes reproducing by external fertilization after the female sheds large numbers of small eggs.

H1.text: Glandular is the term that describes reproducing by external fertilization after the female sheds large numbers of small eggs.

H2.text: Glaucous is the term that describes reproducing by external fertilization after the female sheds large numbers of small eggs.

H3.text: Homozygous is the term that describes reproducing by external fertilization after the female sheds large numbers of small eggs.

A4.text: Ovuliparity, in which fertilization is external, is taken to be the ancestral condition as a rule; the eggs that the female releases into the environment contain unfertilised oocytes, and the male fertilizes them by releasing sperms in proximity to the eggs.

A5.text: In all but special cases of both ovuliparity and oviparity, the overwhelming source of nourishment for the embryo is the nutrients stored in the yolk, pre-deposited in the egg by the reproductive system of the mother (the vitellogenesis).
